inspection items and corrections and stating the batch plant is capable of producing the volume of concrete as required herein. c. submit resume of batch plant operator. batch plant operator must have experience batching rcc on a minimum of two projects and have a minimum of five years' experience operating batch plants. batch plant operator may also fill the role of rcc production superintendent. 1.7.2 laboratory inspection submit a certificate for laboratory accreditation and validation commercial laboratory. additional laboratory requirements are provided in section 01 45 00.00 25, quality control. the government will inspect all laboratories requiring validation for equipment and test procedures prior to the start of any concreting operations for conformance to astm c1077. schedule and provide payment for laboratory inspections. additional payment or a time extension due to failure to acquire the required laboratory validation is not allowed. the laboratory is to maintain this certification for the duration of the project. 1.8 delivery, storage, and handling 1.8.1 cementitious materials 1.8.1.1 transportation when bulk cement or pozzolan is not unloaded from primary carriers directly into weather-tight hoppers at the batching plant, transportation from the railhead, mill, or intermediate storage to the batching plant must be accomplished in adequately designed weather-tight trucks, conveyors, or other means that will protect the material from exposure to moisture. 1.8.1.2 storage furnish cementitious materials in bulk. immediately upon receipt at the site of the work, all cementitious materials must be stored in a dry, section 03 37 23.00 25 page 12 msh sediment retention structure crest raise weather-tight, and properly ventilated structure. all storage facilities must permit easy access for inspection and identification. sufficient materials must be in storage for at least two operating days of continuous placement. in order that cement may not become unduly aged after delivery, use any cement that has been stored at the site for 60 days or more before using cement of lesser age. 1.8.2 aggregate storage fine aggregate and each size of coarse aggregate must be stored in separate size groups adjacent to the batch plant and in such a manner as to prevent the intermingling of size groups or the inclusion of foreign materials in the aggregate. sufficient fine and coarse aggregate must be maintained at the site for at least seven operating days of continuous placement. 1.8.3 chemical admixtures any admixture that has been in storage at the project site for longer than recommended by the manufacturer or that has been subjected to freezing must not be used in the work and must be removed from the site. 1.9 environmental requirements if unusual adverse weather, such as heavy rain, severe cold, high winds, heavy snow, etc., occurs or is forecast to occur during placement, the placement operation must be suspended until conditions improve. 1.9.1 placing during rain rcc must not be placed during rainfall of 0.1 inch/hr or more. during periods of lesser rainfall, placement of rcc may continue if, in the opinion of the co, no damage to the rcc is occurring. work must commence only after excess free surface water and contaminated paste or rcc have been removed and the surface has gained sufficient strength (no less than four hours after the rcc placement was suspended) to prevent rutting, pumping, intermixing of rainwater with the rcc, or other damage to the rcc. when the rcc surface has been contaminated or damaged in any manner, the rcc surface must be washed to break up and remove laitance or mud-like coatings from the surface. any undercut coarse aggregate must be removed. all waste must be removed and disposed of in an approved manner. 1.9.2 hot-weather placement in hot-weather placement the temperature of the rcc must be controlled so that it does not exceed 75.0 degrees f when placed. placement must be suspended as soon as the rcc temperature exceeds 75 degrees f. measures that can be taken to prevent temperatures exceeding 75 degrees f include, but are not limited to, chilling mixing water, sprinkling aggregate stockpiles, use of a canopy to shade the rcc placement areas, placing during nighttime and early morning hours, or restricting placements to cloudy days. use of any of these systems must not be reason for extension of completion dates specified in these specifications. section 03 37 23.00 25 page 13 msh sediment retention structure crest raise part 2 products 2.1 an expansion of 0.10 percent or greater, the aggregate(s) must be rejected or additional testing using astm c1260 and astm c1567 must be performed. the additional testing using astm c1260 and astm c1567 must be performed using the low alkali portland cement in combination with ground granulated blast furnace (ggbf) slag, or class f fly ash. ggbf slag must be used in the range of 40 to 50 percent of the total cementitious material by mass. class f fly ash must be used in the range of 25 to 40 percent of the total cementitious material by mass. 2.1.4.2 quality aggregates delivered to must be reached when the variation in the percent of total moisture tested in accordance with astm c566 and when sampled at the same location will not be more than 0.5 percent during one hour of the two hours prior to placing the material in the batch plant bins and the variation in moisture content when sampled at the same location must not be more than two percent during the last eight hour period that the aggregate remains in the stockpile. the coarse aggregate must be delivered to the mixers with the least amount of free moisture and the least variation in free moisture practicable under the job conditions. under no conditions must the coarse aggregate be delivered to the mixer "dripping wet." section 03 37 23.00 25 page 17 msh sediment retention structure crest raise 2.2 plant and equipment 2.2.1 concrete plant the concrete plant, conveying, placing, compaction, and cleanup systems must have a minimum capacity of at least 200 cubic yards per hour. the concrete plant must be a batch or a continuous mixing plant. 2.2.2 location the concrete plant must be located at the site of the work in the general area indicated in the drawings. 2.2.3 bins and silos separate bins, compartments, or silos must be provided for each size or classification of aggregate and for each of the cementitious materials. the compartments must be of ample size and so constructed that the various materials will be maintained separately under all working conditions. 2.2.4 bulk cement or pozzolan all compartments containing bulk cement or pozzolan must be separated from each other by a free-draining air space. the cement and pozzolan bins must be equipped with filters which allow air passage but preclude the venting of cement or pozzolan into the atmosphere. all filling ports must be clearly marked with a permanent sign stating the contents. 2.2.5 batch plant submit details and data on the concrete plant not later than 30 days after notice to proceed for review by the co. final acceptance of any piece of plant is subject to satisfactory performance during operation. the batch plant must meet the following requirements. 2.2.5.1 batchers aggregate must be weighed in separate weigh batchers with individual scales or may be batched cumulatively. bulk cement and other cementitious materials must each be weighed on a separate scale in a separate weigh batcher. water must be measured by weight or by volume, but it must not be weighed or measured cumulatively with another ingredient. ice must be measured separately by weight. admixtures must be batched separately and must be batched by weight or by volume in accordance with the manufacturers recommendations. 2.2.5.2 water batcher a suitable water-measuring and batching device must be provided that will be capable of measuring and batching the mixing water within the specified tolerances for each batch. the mechanism for delivering water to the mixers must be free from leakage when the valves are closed. the filling and discharge valves for the water batcher must be so interlocked that the discharge valve cannot be opened before the filling valve is fully closed. when a water meter is used, a suitable strainer must be provided ahead of the metering device. section 03 37 23.00 25 page 18 msh sediment retention structure crest raise 2.2.5.3 admixture dispensers a separate batcher or dispenser must be provided for each admixture. each plant must be equipped with the necessary calibration devices that will permit convenient checking of the accuracy of the dispensed volume of the particular admixture. the batching or dispensing devices must be capable of repetitively controlling the batching of the admixtures to the accuracy specified. piping for liquid admixtures must be free from leaks and properly valved to prevent backflow or siphoning. the dispensing system must include a device or devices that must detect and indicate the presence or absence of the admixture or provide a convenient means of visually observing the admixture in the process of being batched or discharged. each system must be capable of ready adjustment to permit varying the quantity of admixture to be batched. each dispenser must be interlocked with the batching and discharge operations so that each admixture is added separately to the batch in solution in a separate portion of the mixing water in a manner to ensure uniform distribution of the admixtures throughout the batch during the required mixing period. storage and handling of admixtures must be in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. 2.2.5.4 moisture control the plant must be capable of ready adjustment to compensate for the varying moisture content of the aggregates and to change the masses of the materials being batched. a moisture meter complying with the provisions of coe crd-c 143 must be provided for measurement of moisture in the fine aggregate. the sensing element must be arranged so that the measurement is made near the batcher charging gate of the sand bin or in the sand batcher. 2.2.5.5 scales adequate facilities must be provided for the accurate measurement and control of each of the materials entering each batch of concrete. the weighing equipment and controls must conform to the applicable requirements of nist hb 44, except that the accuracy must be within 0.2 percent of the scale capacity. provide standard test weights and any other auxiliary equipment required for checking the operating performance of each scale or other measuring device. tests must be made at the frequency required in paragraph tests and inspections in part 3 and in the presence of a government inspector. each weighing unit must include a visible indicator that must indicate the scale load at all stages of the weighing operation and must show the scale in balance at zero load. the weighing equipment must be arranged so that the concrete plant operator can conveniently observe the indicators. 2.2.5.6 operation and accuracy the weighing operation of each material must begin automatically when actuated by one or more starter switches and must end when the designated amount of each material has been reached. these requirements can be met by providing a semiautomatic or automatic batching system as defined by the nrmca cpmb 100. there must be equipment to permit the selection of five preset mixtures each by the movement of not more than two switches or other control devices. the weigh batchers must be so constructed and arranged that the sequence and timing of batcher discharge gates can be controlled to produce a ribboning and mixing of the aggregates, water, admixtures, and cementitious materials as the materials pass through the charging hopper into the mixer. the plant must include provisions to facilitate the section 03 37 23.00 25 page 19 msh sediment retention structure crest raise inspection of all operations at all times. delivery of materials from the batching equipment must be within the following limits of accuracy: material percent of required mass cementitious materials 0 to +2 water 1 aggregate smaller than 1-1/2 inch size 2 aggregate larger than 1-1/2 inch size 3 chemical admixtures 0 to +6 note: when water or chemical admixtures are measured by volume, they must meet the same tolerance percent as stated in the chart. 2.2.5.7 interlocks batchers and mixers must be interlocked so that: a. the charging device of each batcher cannot be actuated until all scales have returned to zero balance within plus or minus 0.2 percent of the scale capacity and each volumetric device has reset to start or has signaled empty. b. the charging device of each batcher cannot be actuated if the discharge device is open. c. the discharge device of each batcher cannot be actuated if the charging device is open. d. the discharge device of each batcher cannot be actuated until the indicated material is within the allowable tolerances. e. admixtures are batched automatically and separately with the water. f. the mixers cannot be discharged until the required mixing time has elapsed. 2.2.5.8 recorder an accurate recorder or recorders must be provided and must conform to the following detailed requirements: a. the recorder must produce a graphical or digital record on a single visible chart or tape of the weight or volume of each material in the batchers at the conclusion of the batching cycle. the record must be produced prior to delivery of the materials to the mixer. after the batchers have been discharged, the recorder must show the return to empty condition. b. a graphical recording or digital printout unit must be completely housed in a single cabinet that must be capable of being locked. c. the chart or tape must be so marked that each batch may be section 03 37 23.00 25 page 20 msh sediment retention structure crest raise permanently identified and so that variations in batch weights of each type of batch can be readily observed. the chart or tape must be easily interpreted in increments not exceeding 0.5 percent of each batch weight. d. the chart or tape must show time of day at intervals of not more than 15 minutes. e. the recorder chart or tape must become the property of the government. f. the recorder must be placed in a position convenient for observation by the concrete plant operator and the government inspector. g. the recorded weights or volumes when compared to the weights or volumes actually batched must be accurate within plus or minus two percent. 2.2.5.9 batch counters the plant must include devices for automatically counting the total number of batches of all concrete batched and the number of batches of each preset mixture. 2.2.5.10 protection the weighing, indicating, recording, and control equipment must be protected against exposure to dust, moisture, and vibration so that there is no interference with proper operation of the equipment. 2.2.6 continuous mixing plant(s) a continuous mixing plant(s) must be capable of producing rcc of the same quality and uniformity as would be produced in a conventional batch plant and must be capable of producing a uniform continuous product (at both maximum and minimum production rates) that is mixed so that complete intermingling of all ingredients occurs without balling, segregation, and wet or dry portions. 2.2.6.1 operation and accuracy an electronic control system must be provided. the control panel must display for each ingredient the designed formula values and the instantaneous percentage values and must record the instantaneous values at a preset time interval and on demand with a multiple copy printer/recorder. the recorder must note formula changes and must print total quantities of each ingredient and total amounts produced on command. there must be weighing devices (belt scale or other) for continuous weighing of individual ingredients and total ingredients. the plant control must not require manual devices to adjust the material flow. the plant must be capable of total manual control operation for a single product at a limited production for short-time durations in the event of loss of electronic control. the electronic control system must incorporate modular replaceable components to reduce down time in the event of control system malfunction. an inventory must be maintained of such replaceable components. the fine aggregate must have a device that monitors its content immediately prior to dispensing into the mixing plant dispensing system. the accuracy of the plant dispensing systems must be within the following limits: section 03 37 23.00 25 page 21 msh sediment retention structure crest raise material percent of required mass pozzolan 0 to +2 percent cement 0 to +2 percent water 1 percent aggregates 2 percent admixtures 0 to +6 percent note: the continuous feeders for each of the ingredients must be calibrated in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications. devices and tools must be maintained at the plant location to check the feeder's calibration at the contracting officer's request. a technician must be provided that is skilled in calibration of the feed devices and the maintenance and repair of the plant control system. the technician must be available within 30 minutes notice during all scheduled plant operations. the technician could be one or more of the contractor's personnel. 2.2.6.2 cement, pozzolan, and aggregate feed cement, pozzolan, and aggregate must be uniformly, continuously, and simultaneously fed (at the proper ratios and quantity for the mixture required) into the mixer by belt, auger, vane feeder, or other acceptable method. the feed bins or silos for each ingredient must be kept sufficiently full and must be of sufficient size to ensure a uniform flow at a constant rate for a specific mixture. the feed bins must have a low-level indicator that both warns the operator and can shut the plant down if insufficient material is available for a uniform and continuous flow. 2.2.6.3 water and admixture dispensers the liquid-dispensing devices must be capable of metering and dispensing within the specified requirements. the liquid valves must be free from leakage in the closed position. the dispensers must have attachments or be installed in such a manner that will permit convenient checking of their accuracy. plumbing must be leak-free and properly valved to prevent backflow and siphoning. the dispenser must be interlocked with the electronic plant control and must warn the operator and shut down the plant if insufficient liquid is available. separate nozzles for each liquid must be properly located at the mixer to assure uniform distribution of each liquid to the materials entering the mixer. 2.2.6.4 continuous mixer(s) the continuous mixer(s) must have proper introduction of ingredients as specified by the manufacturer and must not be charged in excess of the manufacturer's recommended capacity. mixer(s) must be capable of combining the materials into a uniform homogeneous mixture and of discharging this mixture without segregation. the mixer(s) must operate at the blade speed designated by the manufacturer and must be capable of changing retention time of the ingredients in the mixer. this should be accomplished by manually resetting the mixer(s) blade angles. mixing time (ingredient section 03 37 23.00 25 page 22 msh sediment retention structure crest raise retention time in the mixer) must be predicated upon the uniformity, homogeneity, and consistency of the resultant mixture. samples for uniformity testing must be taken at two minute intervals and tested in accordance with coe crd-c 55 and paragraph mixer uniformity requirements below. the mixer(s) must be maintained in satisfactory operating condition and mixer blades must be kept free of hardened concrete. should mixer(s) at any time produce unsatisfactory results, its use must be promptly discontinued until it is repaired. suitable facilities must be provided for obtaining representative samples of concrete for testing. all necessary platforms, shelters, tools, labor, and equipment must be provided for obtaining samples. 2.2.6.5 segregation a means must be used to reduce and minimize segregation and waste which would otherwise result from the continuous stream of concrete being fed into the batch haul devices (concrete buckets, dump trucks, etc.). the equipment must retain the concrete between tracks or other means of transport to prevent the need for stopping the mixer. these devices could include, but not be limited to, small-volume conveyor discharge hopper with a large gate that is automatically opened on a timed interval, thereby dumping a series of small batches into larger batch hoppers, trucks, or truck beds. 2.2.6.6 trial operation not less than seven days prior to commencement of concrete placing, a test of the plant must be made in the presence of a representative of the co to check operational adequacy. the number of cubic yards required to be produced in trial runs must be as directed, but will not exceed 200 cubic yards. all concrete produced in these tests must be wasted or used for purposes other than inclusion in structures covered by this specification. all deficiencies found in plant operation must be corrected to the satisfaction of the co prior to the start of concrete placing operations. mixer uniformity tests by the government will be performed near the end of this trial period. no separate payment will be made to the contractor for labor or materials required by provisions of this paragraph. notify the co of the trial operation not less than seven days prior to the start of the trial operation. 2.2.6.7 equipment. 2.2.7 laboratory areas a room must be provided adjacent to the plant to house the moisture and grading testing equipment for aggregate and to provide working space for the government representative. another room must be provided for testing fresh concrete and for fabricating and initial curing (approximately 72 hours) of concrete test specimens in accordance with astm c31/c31m. the size, arrangement, and location of these rooms will be subject to approval by the co. provide electricity, air-conditioning, heat, and water as required for use in these laboratory areas. section 03 37 23.00 25 page 23 msh sediment retention structure crest raise 2.2.8 mixers mixers must be stationary mixers or pugmill mixers. truck mixers may be used for bedding mortar. mixers may be batch or batch or continuous mixing twin-shaft pugmill mixer must be capable of producing rcc of the same quality and uniformity as would be produced in a conventional plant that meets all the requirements of these specification. all pugmill mixers must meet the requirements of paragraph continuous mixing plant(s) above. 2.2.11 mixer uniformity requirements a. all mixers, except for truck mixers, will be tested by the government in accordance with this paragraph and in accordance with coe crd-c 55. when regular testing is performed, the conventional concrete must meet the limits of any five of the six applicable uniformity requirements, and the rcc must meet the limits of any three of the four applicable uniformity requirements. when abbreviated testing is performed, the concrete must meet only those requirements listed for abbreviated testing. the initial mixer evaluation test must be a regular test and must be performed prior to the start of concrete placement. the concrete proportions used for the evaluation must contain the largest size aggregate on the project and must be as directed by the co. regular testing must consist of performing all tests on three batches of concrete. the range for regular testing must be the average of the ranges of the three batches. abbreviated testing must consist of performing the required tests on a single batch of concrete. the range for abbreviated testing must be the range for one batch. if more than one mixer is used and all are identical in terms of make, type, capacity, condition, speed of rotation, etc., the results of tests on one of the mixers must apply to the others, subject to the approval of the co. mixer evaluations must be performed by the government. provide labor and equipment as directed by the co to assist the government in performing the tests. section 03 37 23.00 25 page 24 msh sediment retention structure crest raise parameter regular tests allowable maximum range for average of 3 batches abbreviated for contractor quality control and government quality assurance testing. 2.2.12.2 sampling aggregates suitable facilities must be provided for readily obtaining representative samples of aggregates for test purposes immediately prior to the material entering the mixer. 2.2.13 transporting and conveying equipment the transporting and conveying equipment must conform to the following requirements. a. the concrete mixtures (rcc and bedding mortar) must be conveyed from the plant mixer(s) to placement as rapidly and as continuously as practical by methods which limit segregation, contamination, and surface drying. b. the rcc must be conveyed from the mixing plant to the structure by section 03 37 23.00 25 page 25 msh sediment retention structure crest raise means of main-line conveyor, end-dump truck, front-end loader, or a combination thereof. c. indicating and signaling devices must be provided for the control and identification of types or classes of concrete as they are mixed and discharged for transfer to the placement site. d. each type or class of concrete must be visually identified by placing a colored tag or other marker as it leaves the mixing plant so that the concrete may be positively identified and placed in the structure in the desired position. 2.2.13.1 trucks truck mixers or agitators used for transporting bedding morter must conform to the applicable requirements of astm c94/c94m. bodies of nonagitating trucks must be smooth, water-tight, metal containers specifically designed to transport concrete, shaped with rounded corners to minimize segregation. 2.2.13.2 belt conveyors belt conveyors must be designed and operated to assure a uniform flow of concrete from mixer or delivery truck to final place of deposit without segregation of ingredients or loss of mortar and must be provided with positive means for preventing segregation of the concrete or loss of mortar at transfer points and the point of placing. the nmsa required in mixture proportions furnished by the government will not be changed to accommodate the belt width. 2.2.14 spreading and remixing equipment the spreading and remixing equipment must conform to the following requirements: a. the primary spreading procedure must be accomplished by dozer. graders or other equipment not specified may be used to facilitate the rcc spreading process only when approved. b. for open, unrestricted areas, the dozer must be a minimum size and weight equivalent to a caterpillar d-6. for restricted placement areas, such as placement of rcc near the dam crest or next to abutments, the dozer must have as a minimum a size and weight equivalent to a caterpillar d-4. c. a minimum of one operating dozer for each 200 cubic yards of rcc placed each hour. the dozers must be equipped with well maintained grousers. a front-end loader with operator must be available to assist with deposition and spreading of rcc as needed in confined areas. d. the equipment must be maintained in good operating condition. the equipment must not leak or drip oil, grease, or other visible contaminants onto the rcc surface. e. all equipment used for spreading and remixing that leaves the surface of the structure for maintenance or repairs or, for any other reason, must be cleaned of all contaminants by an approved method before returning to the structure surface. under no conditions must a dozer or other tracked vehicle be operated on other than fresh uncompacted rcc except to facilitate startup operations for each lift section 03 37 23.00 25 page 26 msh sediment retention structure crest raise and by approved procedures. 2.2.15 compaction equipment submit a listing of the equipment proposed for transporting, handling, depositing, spreading, and compacting the concrete for review by the co not later than 30 days after notice to proceed. include site drawings or sketches with locations of equipment and placement site. the compaction equipment must conform to the following requirements. 2.2.15.1 primary rollers self-propelled vibratory rollers must be used for primary rolling and must be double-drum. they must transmit a dynamic impact to the surface through a smooth steel drum by means of revolving weights, eccentric shafts, or other equivalent methods. the compactor must have a minimum gross mass of 20,000 pounds and must produce a minimum dynamic force of 350 pounds/linear inch of drum width. the operating frequency must be variable in the approximate range of 1,700 to 3,000 cycles per minute. the amplitude must be adjustable between 0.015 and 0.04 inches. the roller must be capable of full compaction in both forward and reverse directions. the roller must be operated at speeds not exceeding 2.2 ft/s. within the range of the operating capability of the equipment, the co may direct or approve variations to the frequency, amplitude, and speed of operation which result in the specified density at the fastest production rate. 2.2.15.2 small vibratory rollers small vibratory rollers must be used to compact the rcc where the larger vibratory rollers specified above cannot maneuver. the rollers must compact the rcc to the required density and must be so demonstrated during construction of the test section. small vibratory rollers cannot compact the rcc to the same density and thickness as the primary rollers; therefore, when small rollers are used, total lift thickness of the rcc layer or lift must be reduced to not over 6 inches uncompacted thickness to permit adequate compaction. rollers must have independent speed and vibration controls and must be capable of a wide range of speed adjustments. 2.2.15.3 tampers (rammers) the tampers must compact the rcc to the required density and must be so demonstrated during construction of the test section. tampers cannot compact the rcc to the same density and thickness as the primary rollers; therefore, when tampers are used, thickness of each rcc layer that is to be compacted must be reduced to not more than 6 inches uncompacted thickness to assure adequate compaction. 2.2.16 truck-mounted vacuum pickup system a truck-mounted vacuum pickup system must be provided for various cleanup operations from the beginning of foundation cleanup to final placement of job rcc. the unit(s) must be capable of pumping 4,500 cubic feet of air per minute through an 8 inch diameter opening and capable of pumping water at a minimum rate of 2,000 gpm. the equipment must be maintained in good operating condition. the equipment must not leak cleanup water and other debris during equipment operation or transit. the equipment must not leak or drip oil, grease, or other visible contamination onto the rcc. section 03 37 23.00 25 page 27 msh sediment retention structure crest raise 2.2.17 other motorized equipment all other equipment (backhoe with vibratory plate, backhoe with immersion vibrators, backhoe with mandrel for inserting contraction joint plates, wash trucks, etc.) necessary for the successful completion of rcc production, but not previously discussed within these specifications (or determined to be necessary during the course of the work), must be approved prior to actual use. such equipment must not result in any damage to the rcc, must be maintained in good operating condition, and must be operated by skilled contractor-provided personnel. 2.2.18 nuclear density gauge tests to determine the density of both the uncompacted and compacted rcc must be made by the contractor using a two-probe nuclear density gauge supplied by the contractor. the nuclear density gauge must meet the applicable requirements of astm c1040/c1040m. the gauge must be capable of taking readings along a horizontal path between the probes at 2 inch increments from 2 inches from the surface to 24 inches below the surface. the gauge and operator must be made available to the government until completion of all rcc production at no additional cost. obtain all permits and certifications for the equipment and the operators. 2.2.19 calibration nuclear gauges must have been factory calibrated within six months of rcc placement. construct, at no additional costs to the government, three conventional concrete test blocks using rcc coarse aggregates and rcc fine aggregate, and with dimensions 12 inches larger than the gauge dimensions. the concrete must be formulated to have densities of approximately 130, 145, and 160 lb/cu ft using the rcc materials and so far as possible, similar relative proportions. completed blocks must be weighed and measured to determine unit weight. gauge calibration constants must be adjusted for performance on these blocks at least seven days prior to the evaluation of test strips. remedy any inconsistencies in gauge performance prior to the start of rcc placement. after the start of rcc placement, gauges must be field recalibrated against cast blocks every 24 hours. part 3 execution 3.1 preparation for placing 3.1.1 placing schedule at least seven days before starting rcc production, a detailed schedule must be submitted indicating intended daily and weekly production rates that, when followed, will meet the beginning and ending specified rcc production dates. this rcc lift plan is to include the plan and sequence of work, including graphical depictions of lifts based off of the foundation survey. after initiation of rcc production, the contractor's schedule must be updated and adjusted on a weekly basis for the duration of the rcc placement. if it becomes apparent for any reason that the contractor is not pursuing a schedule that will meet the specified rcc production dates, actions necessary to increase the production rate must be taken so that production is once again on schedule, within five calendar days after written notice. also, if not back on schedule by the end of the seven day period, the government reserves the right at this time to direct the contractor, at no additional cost to the government, to increase the amount and size of crews and equipment. section 03 37 23.00 25 page 28 msh sediment retention structure crest raise 3.1.2 rcc orientation session prior to or in conjunction with the construction of the rcc test section, supervisors and all other contractor personnel which are expected to participate in the production of rcc for this job (including laborers, equipment operators, foremen, and qc and inspection staff) must participate in a two-hour orientation session organized by the contractor and led by their rcc specialist. provide a facility suitable for slide and videotape presentation. the intent is to orient all individuals on the goals of the rcc placement process, provide clarification of specification requirements if requested, and be provided orientation as to what constitutes good construction practices. additional orientation sessions will also be made available to, and must be attended by, all new contractor personnel who are subsequently hired and that will be involved with the production of the rcc. 3.1.3 aggregate production schedule aggregate production and initial stockpiling must begin and must be producing acceptable material by not later than seven days in advance of the time when placement of the rcc test section is expected to begin. submit descriptions and details for all methods and operations proposed for aggregate and concrete operations including daily and weekly production rates, not later than 15 days after notice to proceed for review and approval for conformance with specifications. 3.1.4 rcc test section prior to placement of any rcc, construct a test section. the purpose of the test section is to demonstrate the suitability of the contractor's equipment, methods, and personnel. the test section must be at least three lifts in height and be at least 100 feet long and 20 feet wide at the top. the site of the test section must be approved. trial batches can be done in conjunction with the test section. after evaluation and assessment of the test section by the co, dispose of the test section in an approved manner. under no circumstances must the test section be incorporated into or become a part of the permanent rcc structure. the test section must demonstrate sustained plant production rates, and batching, mixing, transporting, spreading, and compaction procedures. it must also demonstrate the vertical face construction method along one side, the sloped face construction method along another side, procedures for foundation and concrete surface preparation and cleanup, procedures for placement of concrete, bedding mortar, and other conventional concrete. do not begin rcc operations for the main structure until testing and evaluations by the government have been completed, and it has been demonstrated to the satisfaction of the co that all specification requirements were met. following completion of test section construction, 10 days must be allowed for testing and evaluations. if the contractor does not meet requirements as specified, an additional test section or sections must be constructed at no additional cost to the government. the date of the test section construction must be provided at least seven days in advance. 3.1.5 surface preparation 3.1.5.1 cleaning all lift surfaces including any rcc, dental concrete, concrete, bedding mortar, or other conventional concrete placed adjacent to and at the same section 03 37 23.00 25 page 29 msh sediment retention structure crest raise time as the rcc must be cleaned prior to placing any additional concrete thereon. after cleaning, concrete and bedding mortar are to be used specifically for achieving bond between different types of concrete and foundation and eliminating and preventing segregation or voids along margins or rcc placements. no surfaces to receive concrete or bedding mortar must be covered with rcc until the prepared surfaces have been accepted in writing and that acceptance has been recorded on an approved checkout form. all surfaces upon which rcc or any bedding mortar placed must be moist (but contain no visible free water). prior to placing any concrete adjacent to and at the same time as the rcc, all surfaces must be clean and free of loose, unkeyed, or deteriorated rock; all mud and silt accumulations; vegetation; laitance; puddles or ponds of free surface water; coatings; and any other detrimental materials. high-pressure water jetting, or wet sandblasting, followed by mild high-volume, low-pressure washing, must be used on all hardened concrete surfaces (cold joints) as necessary for the removal of laitance, coatings, stains, or other difficult-to-remove contaminants. high-volume low-pressure water washing or water jetting may be used for removal of loose materials. adequate equipment with operators must be on hand at the site to clean all surfaces in conformance with these specifications without disrupting in any way the rcc production as scheduled. 3.1.5.2 high-volume low-pressure washing washing of loose materials can be accomplished with high-volume low-pressure water washing or air water jetting using equipment of similar design to that used in large-scale foundation cleanups. the air-water jets must have 1 1/2 inch nozzles, a water supply of at least 30 gpm, and compressed air at the jet of 80 to 120 psi. the low-pressure water jets must have one inch nozzles available and a capacity of at least 200 gpm for truck-mounted devices. 3.1.5.3 high-pressure water jet a stream of water under a pressure of not less than 1,500 psi for rcc and 4,000 psi for conventional concrete must be used for cleaning all cold joint surfaces, or surfaces with laitance, mortar coatings, stains, or other difficult-to-remove contaminants. there must be no undercutting of coarse-size aggregates. aggregate particles that are undercut must be removed. for cleaning large open areas larger than 5,000 square feet, the high-pressure water jet system must be truck-mounted. for cleaning small or confined areas, the high-pressure water jet system must be portable. 3.1.5.4 waste disposal any waste water employed in cutting, washing, and rinsing of concrete surfaces, and any other surface water must not stain, or affect exposed surfaces of the structure(s) or damage the environment of the project area. the method of disposal must be subject to approval. 3.2 placing 3.2.1 procedures it is the intent of this contract to raise the structure at essentially the same level across the entire horizontal surface area. as the advancing edge of the lift progresses, the exposed leading edges must be kept "live" by progressively placing out from the advancing edge in a sloping and uniform fan-like manner. rcc must be deposited (from the conveyor, section 03 37 23.00 25 page 30 msh sediment retention structure crest raise end-dump truck, or front-end loader) on the uncompacted rcc of the advancing edge in a forward direction from the dump pile. rcc must not be placed in consecutive or consistent lanes. the dump location must be varied to avoid "lane" construction. the interval between batch plant mixing and final rcc compaction must be no greater than 45 minutes. final compaction is defined as: any rcc lift composed of layers that have been worked twice by dozer grousers, receives four passes with the vibratory roller, and meets the density requirements. 3.2.2 bedding mortar the bedding mortar must be applied to the existing surface following any required cleanup. the bedding mortar must be applied not more than 15 minutes ahead of rcc placement, unless otherwise approved. the bedding mortar must be used between hardened conventional concrete and rcc, between different rcc placements where cold joints occur, and other locations as directed or as shown in the drawings. the bedding mortar must have an average thickness after application of between 1/4 and 1/2 inch and must cover 100 percent of the lift area. 3.2.3 lift thickness the total lift thickness after final compaction by the vibratory roller must be 12 inches. 3.2.4 depositing, spreading, and remixing after the rcc has been deposited, the rcc must be spread by dozers into gently sloping layers, approximately 6 inches thick, that will, after final compaction of the several layers by the vibratory roller, result in the specified lift thickness. during the spreading process, the dozer operators must continuously work the rcc surfaces with the dozer blade and grousers in a manner to remix any rcc that may contain pockets of segregated material and to compact the material. all surfaces of each layer must receive at least two passes with the grousers. the dozers must be operating continuously during the spreading process, even if this action results in more than two passes. a front-end loader with operator must be available to assist with depositing and spreading rcc as needed in confined areas, at the abutments, and at other locations approved or directed. in no case must the rcc, or bedding mortar be allowed to dry. under no conditions must a dozer or other tracked vehicle be operated on other than fresh uncompacted rcc except at the start of each lift placement to facilitate startup operations, and then only by an approved procedure. no rcc or other concrete must be placed on a previous lift which has not met specification. unacceptable material must be removed. 3.2.5 compaction/consolidation after spreading and working with the dozers, the top surface of each lift must be compacted with a minimum of four, plus as many additional passes with a self-propelled double-drum vibratory roller operating in the vibratory mode as are required to obtain a minimum of 98 percent of the theoretical density. a round trip over the same material must count as two passes (i.e., from point a to point b and return to point a by the same route is two passes). rollers must not be operated in the vibratory mode unless they are moving section 03 37 23.00 25 page 31 msh sediment retention structure crest raise 3.2.5.1 theoretical density (td) determination the td is defined as the theoretical density (unit weight) of the concrete, pounds per cubic foot, computed to including air content. the td value to be used during construction will be determined using job mixture proportions and contractor supplied materials; and, using compaction techniques suitable for rcc, and following the appropriate testing procedures used to determined theoretical unit weight of concrete as described as in astm c138/c138m. 3.2.5.2 required compaction density all rcc must be compacted to a minimum of 98 percent of the td value. the anticipated td, estimated from laboratory test data is approximately 160 pounds per cubic foot. 3.2.5.3 density determination of compacted rcc density must be measured using a nuclear density meter in accordance with astm c1040/c1040m. rcc density value determinations must be made throughout the course of rcc placement to assure that the rcc is compacted to a minimum 98 percent of the td and detect segregation or voids throughout the rcc. submit findings of all tests as part of the concrete strength report. 3.2.5.4 additional compaction if more than four passes are required to achieve the required density, the additional passes must be made at no additional cost to the government. 3.2.6 lift joints the entire rcc mass must be placed with sufficient continuity so that it hardens and acts as one monolithic block without discontinuous joints or potential planes of separation. all lift joints must be kept clean, uncontaminated, free from ponded water, and continuously moist until placement of the succeeding rcc or other concrete. 3.2.6.1 regular lift-joint treatment a. lift joints that have not hardened or dried and are less than 72 hours old must be given the regular lift-joint treatment. submit the method and equipment proposed for joint cleanup and waste disposal for review by the co not later than 30 days after notice to proceed for conformance with specifications. regular lift-joint treatment and maintenance must include: (1) maintaining 100 percent of each compacted lift-joint surface continuously moist, (2) if necessary, removing all loose contaminants or deteriorated rcc by low-pressure washing or vacuuming, and (3) application of a 1/4 to 1/2 inch thick bedding mortar over the entire placement surface area immediately before placement of the next lift. b. for regular lift-joint treatment, no washing or vacuuming will be necessary provided damage or contamination of the lift surface is section 03 37 23.00 25 page 32 msh sediment retention structure crest raise prevented. 3.2.6.2 cold joints a. a cold joint is any vertical or horizontal rcc surface: (1) that does not receive the next rcc lift within 72 hours, (2) in which the rcc has been allowed to dry, or (3) that has been contaminated to the extent that contaminants cannot be removed using low-pressure water. b. cold joints must be prepared for the next lift by the methods and procedures in paragraph surface preparation above, prior to resumption of rcc placement. following this initial preparation, the cold-joint surface must be kept continuously moist until application of the bedding mortar. whenever a cold joint at any edge or end of any lift occurs, it must be located at least 30 feet from the location of other cold joints that may have previously occurred in the same direction along previous lifts. 3.2.6.3 unplanned cold joints cold joints between adjacent placements of rcc must not be scheduled. however, if an unplanned joint occurs, it must be treated as follows: a. unplanned cold-joints will be treated as described above. additionally they must be treated as described hereafter. b. shoulders must be broken down and feathered out such that the vertical rise does not exceed the layer height for each horizontal distance equal to the roller width, and c. the hardened rcc surface must be prepared for receiving the next layer of rcc by cleaning with air supplemented with water to remove all loose material. rcc surfaces which are to receive additional concrete are considered to be cold joints if the hardened rcc surface is over 72 hours old, or has been contaminated to the extent that contaminants cannot be removed using low pressure water. 3.2.6.4 vertical joints joints for sloping, near-vertical or vertical rcc surfaces are considered to be vertical joints. a vertical joint most often will occur when an rcc placement is terminated before the entire rcc placement for that lift has been completed. when it does become apparent that placement of rcc will be terminated prior to completion of a lift, the rcc spreading procedure at the leading zone of the placement must be adjusted to provide a gradual tapered slope to complete that lift. the taper must be no steeper than 25 horizontal on one vertical. where the tapered slope meets the underlying hardened lift surface, care must be taken to prevent or remove any segregated or uncompacted material. the tapered surface must be compacted in accordance with paragraph compaction/consolidation above. prior to resumption of rcc placements, the tapered surface must be prepared in accordance with paragraph surface preparation above. section 03 37 23.00 25 page 33 msh sediment retention structure crest raise 3.2.7 downstream face the downstream sloped face of the dam and the exposed slopes of the stilling basin training walls must be constructed using sacrificial rcc on 1.0 vertical to 0.9 horizontal slope. the slope must be constructed to the tolerances specified. each rcc lift must be overbuilt at least 12 inches, and it must subsequently be trimmed to the surface smoothness tolerance. trimming must be performed before the rcc is more than 48 hours old. the process must be demonstrated during the test section. trimming must be done in such a manner to prevent damage to the surface and interior rcc. 3.3 curing and protection submit the curing media and methods to be used for review to the co 14 days before concrete placement begins for conformance with specifications. 3.3.1 curing the surface of every rcc lift must be kept continuously moist, commencing immediately after compaction, by use of water trucks equipped with fog sprayers for 14 days or until the surface is covered with the next lift. uncompacted sacrificial rcc, need not be cured. concrete that is moist cured must be maintained continuously, not periodically, wet for the duration of the entire curing period. water for curing must comply with the requirements of paragraph entitled water. if the water or mats cause staining or discoloration of permanently exposed concrete surfaces, the surfaces must be cleaned by a method approved by the co. when wood or metal forms are left in place during curing, the forms must be kept continuously wet, except for sealed insulation curing in cold weather. rcc may be cured with saturated cotton or burlap mats in lieu of the approved fog spraying equipment. the rcc must meet a 7 day minimum compressive strength of 2,500 psi prior to releasing water over the newly placed concrete. 3.3.2 hot-weather protection when ambient air temperatures exceeds 90 degrees f and as soon as the conventional concrete and rcc is sufficiently hard to withstand washing of surface mortar, water by fog spraying must be applied in a controlled manner to provide evaporative cooling. water must be applied at such a rate that it quickly evaporates and such that the surface remains continuously moist without ponding. in addition, when surface materials begin to dry and while the rcc placement, spreading, and compaction process is still underway and until the concrete has sufficiently hardened to permit the above water spray, hand-held fog spraying must be applied to the concrete surfaces as directed to prevent drying out of concrete materials and replace moisture lost to evaporation. these hot-weather protection procedures will require additional labor(s) to assure complete coverage of the entire surface areas to prevent unacceptable damage to the rcc and conventional concrete. submit a description of the materials and methods proposed for protection of the concrete, when concrete is to be placed under hot-weather conditions, to the co for review 30 days in advance of anticipated need date. section 03 finishing the ambient temperature of spaces adjacent to surfaces being finished must be not less than 50 degrees f. in hot weather when the rate of evaporation of surface moisture, as determined by use of figure 2.1.5 of aci 305r, may reasonably be expected to exceed 0.2 lb/sq ft per hour, provisions for windbreaks, shading, fog spraying, or wet covering with a light-colored material must be made in advance of placement, and such protective measures must be taken as quickly as finishing operations will allow. all unformed surfaces that are not to be covered by additional concrete or backfill must have a float finish, unless a trowel finish is specified, and must be true to the elevation shown. surfaces to receive additional concrete or backfill must be brought to the elevation shown in the drawings and left true and regular. exterior surfaces must be sloped for drainage unless otherwise shown or as directed. joints must be carefully made with a jointing or edging tool. the finished surfaces must be protected from stains or abrasions. 3.5 tests and inspections 3.5.1 general perform the inspection and tests as described below, and based upon the results of these inspections and tests, he must take the action required and submit reports as required. when, in the opinion of the co, the concreting operation is out of control, concrete placement must cease. the laboratory performing the tests must be on-site and must conform with astm c1077. the individuals who sample and test concrete or the constituents of concrete as required in this specification must have demonstrated a knowledge and ability to perform the necessary test procedures equivalent to the aci minimum guidelines for certification of concrete field testing technicians, grade i. the individual who performs the inspection must have demonstrated a knowledge and ability equivalent to section 03 37 23.00 25 page 35 msh sediment retention structure crest raise the aci minimum guidelines for certification of concrete construction inspector (cci), level ii. the government will inspect the laboratory, equipment, and test procedures prior to start of concreting operations and at least once per year thereafter for conformance with astm c1077. 3.5.2 testing and inspection requirements 3.5.2.1 fine aggregate 3.5.2.1.1 grading at least once during each shift when the concrete plant is operating, there must be one sieve analysis and fineness modulus determination in accordance with astm c136/c136m, astm c117, and coe crd-c 104 for the fine aggregate or for each fine aggregate if it is batched in more than one size or classification. the location at which samples are taken may be selected by the contractor as the most advantageous for control. however, the contractor is responsible for delivering fine aggregate to the mixer within specification limits. the results must be recorded on a sheet on which are also shown the specification limits applicable to the project. 3.5.2.1.2 fineness-modulus control chart results for fineness modulus must be grouped in sets of three consecutive tests, and the average and range of each group must be plotted on a control chart. the upper and lower control limits for average must be drawn 0.10 units above and below the target fineness modulus, and the upper control limit for range must be 0.20. 3.5.2.1.3 corrective action for fine aggregate grading when the amount passing on any sieve is outside the specification limits, the fine aggregate must be immediately resampled and retested. if there is another failure on any sieve, the fact must immediately be reported to the co. whenever a point on the fineness modulus control chart, either for average or range, is beyond one of the control limits, the frequency of testing must be doubled. if two consecutive points are beyond the control limits, the process must be considered out of control and concreting must be stopped. the co must be notified, and immediate steps must be taken to rectify the situation. after two consecutive points have fallen within the control limits, testing at the normal frequency may be resumed. 3.5.2.1.4 moisture content testing when in the opinion of the co the electric moisture meter is not operating satisfactorily, there must be at least four tests for moisture content in accordance with astm c566 during each eight hour period of mixing plant operation. the times for the tests must be selected randomly within the eight hour period. an additional test must be made whenever the slump is out of control or excessive variation in workability is reported by the placing foreman. when an electric moisture meter is operating satisfactorily, at least two direct measurements of moisture content must be made per week to check the calibration of the meter. the results of tests for moisture content must be used to adjust the added water in the control of the batch plant. 3.5.2.1.5 moisture content corrective action whenever the moisture content of the fine aggregate changes by 0.5 percent section 03 37 23.00 25 page 36 msh sediment retention structure crest raise or more from the previous sample, the scale settings for the fine aggregate batcher and water batcher must be adjusted (directly or by means of a moisture compensation device). 3.5.2.2 coarse aggregate 3.5.2.2.1 grading at least once during each shift in which the concrete plant is operating, there must be a sieve analysis in accordance with astm c136/c136m for each size of coarse aggregate. the location at which samples are taken may be selected by the contractor as the most advantageous for production control. a test record of samples of aggregate taken at the same locations must show the results of the current test as well as the average results of the five most recent tests including the current test. the contractor may adopt limits for control coarser than the specification limits for samples taken other than as delivered to the mixer to allow for degradation during handling. when facilities are available to test samples five times as large as those required in astm c136/c136m, no averaging must be done. 3.5.2.2.2 corrective action for grading when the amount passing any sieve is outside the specification limits, the coarse aggregate must be immediately resampled and retested. if the second sample fails on any sieve, that fact must be reported to the co. where two consecutive averages of five tests (or two consecutive tests where large samples are used) are outside specification limits, the operation must be considered out of control, and that fact must be reported to the co, concreting must be stopped, and immediate steps must be taken to correct the grading. 3.5.2.2.3 coarse aggregate moisture content a test for moisture content of each size group of coarse aggregate must be made at least once a shift. when two consecutive readings for smallest size coarse aggregate differ by more than one percent, frequency of testing must be increased to that specified previously for fine aggregate. 3.5.2.2.4 coarse aggregate moisture corrective action whenever the moisture content of any size of coarse aggregate changes by 0.5 percent or more from the previous sample, the scale setting for the coarse aggregate batcher and the water batcher must be adjusted to compensate for this. 3.5.2.2.5 material finer than the no. 200 sieve when in the opinion of the co, a problem exists in connection with the cleanliness of the coarse aggregate, tests must be made in accordance with astm c117. testing frequency must be as directed. 3.5.2.2.6 corrective action for material finer than the no. 200 sieve when material finer than the no. 200 sieve exceeds one percent of the weight of the coarse aggregate finer than 1 1/2 inch or 0.5 percent of the weight of the aggregate coarser than 1 1/2 inch, the co must be notified, and steps, such as washing or other corrective action, must be initiated immediately. section 03 37 23.00 25 page 37 msh sediment retention structure crest raise 3.5.2.3 quality of aggregates 3.5.2.3.1 frequency of quality tests prior to submitting samples for mixture proportioning studies, perform the tests for aggregate quality in the following list. in addition, after the start of concrete placement, perform tests for aggregate quality during concrete or aggregate production, in accordance with the following frequency schedule. samples tested after the start of concrete placement must be taken immediately prior to entering the concrete mixer. frequency property fine aggregate coarse aggregate test specific gravity every 30 days every 30 days astm c127 astm c128 absorption every 30 days every 30 days astm c127 astm c128 flat and elongate not applicable every 30 days astm d4791 3.5.2.3.2 corrective action for aggregate quality if the result of a quality test fails to meet the requirements for quality during submittal of samples for mixture-proportioning studies or immediately prior to start of concrete placement, production procedures or materials must be changed and additional tests must be performed until the material meets the quality requirements prior to proceeding with either mixture-proportioning studies or starting concrete placement. after concrete placement commences, whenever the result of a test for quality fails the requirements, the test must be rerun immediately. if the second test fails the quality requirement, the fact must be reported to the co and immediate steps taken to rectify the situation. 3.5.2.4 compressive strength testing at least one set of test specimens will be made each day on each different mixture placed during each shift. additional sets of test cylinders will be made, as directed by the co, when the mixture proportions are changed or when low strengths have been detected. a random sampling plan will be developed and approved by the co prior to the start of construction. sampling must be random in accordance with the requirements of astm d3665. a set of test specimens for concrete with a 90-day strength will consist of six cylinders, two tested at seven days, two at 28 days, and two at 90 days. test specimens will be 6 inch diameter by 12 inches, molded in accordance with astm c1176/1176m or astm c1435/c1435m, protected and cured in accordance with astm c31/c31m, and tested in accordance with astm c39/c39m. all compressive-strength tests will be reported immediately to the co. quality control charts must be kept for individual strength tests, moving average for strength, and moving average for range for each mixture. the charts must be similar to those found in aci 214r. 3.5.2.5 vebe consistency for each set of strength specimens as described above a vebe consistency in accordance with astm c1170/c1170m must be completed. both the vebe time section 03 37 23.00 25 page 38 msh sediment retention structure crest raise and density must be reported as part of the contractor's quality control program. 3.5.2.6 scales 3.5.2.6.1 weighing accuracy the accuracy of the scales must be checked by test weights at least once a month for conformance with the applicable requirements of paragraphs batch plant and continuous mixing plant both in part 2. such tests must also be made as directed whenever there are variations in properties of the fresh concrete that could result from batching errors. 3.5.2.6.2 batching and recording accuracy once a week the accuracy of each batching and recording device must be checked during a weighing operation by noting and recording the required weight, recorded weight, and the actual weight batched. confirm that the calibration devices described in paragraph batch plant in part 2 for checking the accuracy of dispensed admixtures are operating properly. if a continuous mixing plant is provided, the accuracy and operation of all feeding and dispensing units must be checked before the start of operation each day. 3.5.2.6.3 scales corrective action when the weighing accuracy or batching accuracy does not comply with specification requirements, the plant must not be operated until necessary adjustments or repairs have been made. discrepancies in recording accuracies must be corrected immediately. 3.5.2.7 concrete plant control the measurement of all constituent materials including cementitious materials, each size of aggregate, water, and admixtures must be continuously controlled. the aggregate weights and amount of added water must be adjusted as necessary to compensate for free moisture in the aggregates. a report must be prepared indicating type and source of cement used, type and source of pozzolan or slag used, amount and source of admixtures used, aggregate source, the required aggregate and water weights per cubic yard, amount of water as free moisture in each size of aggregate, and the as-mixed aggregate and water weights per cubic yard for each class of concrete placed during plant operation. 3.5.2.8 field density 3.5.2.8.1 testing and checking density must be determined for at least eight locations per rcc lift with a calibrated nuclear density gauge in accordance with astm c1040/c1040m. densities must be taken at depths of 4 and 8 inches. if the densities at 4 and 8 inches conflict, acceptance must be at the 8 inch depth. 3.5.2.8.2 action required whenever the nuclear gauge indicates density less than the specified density, a retest must be made. if the retest indicates unacceptable density, the co's representative must be notified, additional rolling must be immediately provided, and a determination must be made as to whether the section 03 37 23.00 25 page 39 msh sediment retention structure crest raise lower density resulted from insufficient passes of the roller or a change in the mix properties. if the mix properties have changed, adjustments such as increasing or decreasing the moisture content must be made at the batch plant. if the problem persists, the co may adjust the proportions of aggregates, cement, and pozzolan. if the lower density is the result of incomplete rolling, the operator must be notified and the co may require removal of the incompletely compacted material at no cost to the government. 3.5.2.9 inspection before placing foundation or construction joints, forms, and embedded items must be inspected in sufficient time prior to each concrete placement to certify to the co that they are ready to receive concrete. the results of each inspection must be reported in writing. the inspection of the lift surfaces of the rcc will be a continuing activity and must be accomplished in accordance with paragraph regular lift-joint treatment above. 3.5.2.10 placing inspection 3.5.2.10.1 inspection provide full time supervision of all placing operations to insure that the correct quality of rcc, conventional concrete, or grout is placed in each location and that all other aspects of the placing operation are performed in accordance with the contract. during placing operations, the quality control staff must measure and record concrete temperatures in accordance with astm c1064/c1064m, ambient temperature hourly, record weather conditions, time of placement, yardage placed, and method of placement. 3.5.2.10.2 corrective action the placing foreman must not permit placing to begin until he has verified that an adequate number of vibrators, spreaders, and compactors in working order and with competent operators are available. placing must not be continued if any conventional concrete is inadequately consolidated or if any lift of rcc is not fully compacted. additional compaction, if necessary, must be performed in accordance with paragraph additional compaction above. if any batch of conventional concrete fails to meet the temperature requirements, immediate steps must be taken to improve temperature controls. 3.5.2.11 vibrator tests 3.5.2.11.1 vibrator testing and use the frequency and amplitude of each vibrator must be determined in accordance with coe crd-c 521 prior to initial use and at least once a month when concrete is being placed. additional tests must be made as directed when a vibrator does not appear to be adequately consolidating the concrete. the frequency must be determined while the vibrator is operating in concrete with the tachometer being held against the upper end of the vibrator head while almost submerged and just before the vibrator is withdrawn from the concrete. the amplitude must be determined with the head vibrating in air. two measurements must be taken, one near the tip and another near the upper end of the vibrator head, and these results averaged. the make, model, type, and size of the vibrator and frequency and amplitude results must be reported in writing. in addition, the self-propelled vibratory rollers, as specified in part 2, paragraph primary rollers, must be checked for frequency and amplitude prior to use and once section 03 37 23.00 25 page 40 msh sediment retention structure crest raise every three months when rcc is being placed. 3.5.2.11.2 vibrator corrective action any vibrator not meeting the requirements of paragraph vibrators must be immediately removed from service and repaired or replaced. 3.5.2.12 curing inspection 3.5.2.12.1 moist curing inspections at least twice each shift, and twice per day on nonwork days an inspection must be made of all areas subject to moist curing. the surface moisture condition must be noted and recorded. 3.5.2.12.2 moist curing corrective action when a daily inspection report lists an area of inadequate curing, immediate corrective action must be taken, and the required curing period for those areas must be extended by one day. 3.5.2.13 cold-weather and hot-weather protection at least once each shift and once per day on nonwork days an inspection must be made of all areas subject to cold-weather or hot-weather protection. any deficiencies must be noted, corrected, and reported. 3.5.2.14 cold-weather and hot-weather protection corrective action when a daily inspection report lists deficiencies, the deficiency must be corrected immediately and the period of protection extended for one day. 3.5.3 reports all results of tests or inspections conducted must be reported informally as they are completed and in writing daily. a weekly report must be prepared for the updating of control charts covering the entire period from the start of the construction season through the current week. during periods of cold-weather protection, reports of pertinent temperatures must be made daily. these requirements do not relieve the contractor of the obligation to report certain failures astm d6103/d6103m (2017; e 2021) standard test method for flow consistency of controlled low strength material (clsm) 1.2 summary this section specifies ready-mix controlled low strength material (clsm) for the following applications: filling of the 30 pipes and entire valve pit located in the outlet works structure to be abandoned. 1.3 definitions a. ready-mix clsm is used for utility pipe backfill, and is also known as controlled density fill or flowable fill as defined in aci 229r. clsm differs from portland cement concrete as it contains a low cementitious content to reduce strength development for possible future removal. chemical admixtures may also be used in clsm to modify performance properties of strength, flow, set and hydraulic conductivity. pumpable mixes are available. b. clsm must have compressive strength properties per paragraph mix compressive strength below. 1.4 submittals government approval is required for submittals with a "g" designation; submittals not having a "g" designation are for information only. when used, a designation following the "g" designation identifies the office that will review the submittal for the government. submit the following g 1.5 quality assurance 1.5.1 manufacturer clsm must be manufactured by a ready-mix concrete producer with a minimum of one year experience in the production of similar products. 1.6 delivery, ingredients. truck mixed clsm must have undergone a minimum of 100 and maximum of 300 drum revolutions prior to placement. the contractor may not add water to the mix after initial batching and transport. submit a clsm truck mix revolutions report. 1.8 project conditions perform work only when existing and forecasted weather conditions are within the limits established by the manufacturer of driven flow events are rare during the in-water-work-period, but they have occurred within the gage record. the river forecast can be one way of staying informed if flows are expected to change. be activity, including the type(s) of culverts, the plan for installation, and the plan for filling with concrete upon completion of use. a construction photo of the temporary works developed in 2012 is included in drawing c-008 care and diversion of water during construction. the drawing illustrates areas that can be used for diversion and those that cannot. 1.5 professional engineer a registered professional engineer must design the river diversion system. the professional engineer must concur with the river diversion plan. the professional engineer must inspect the river diversion system during initial construction, whenever there is a change in configuration, and during high river flow events. the professional engineer must produce a river diversion report for each site visit documenting all observations, recommendations, and updates to the river diversion system. the professional engineer must be available to meet with the contracting officer at any time throughout the contract duration. update the river diversion plan and re-submit with any changes. submit no later than one day after each site visit by professional engineer. part 2 products not used. part 3 execution 3.1 cofferdams and culverts a. the contractor may construct cofferdams and use culverts as necessary for the river diversion system. as a minimum, the river diversion system must be capable of passing a river discharge of 860 cubic feet per second without flooding the worksite. this flow has a 10 percent chance of exceedance in any given year between july 1 to september 30. extending the work any later would likely experience increased flows and affect the contractor's design. b. the contractor is allowed to install steel or concrete culverts within the rcc structure, for the purpose of river diversion, as long as the following requirements are met: (1) the culverts are strong enough to support the loads from the rcc structure during the river diversion time period. (2) no rcc compacted against the culverts below their springline. (3) place a minimum of two feet of conventional concrete, with a compressive strength no less than 3,000 pounds per square inch, around the culverts below their springline. section 30 00 01.00 25 page 3 msh sediment retention structure crest raise (4) culverts are anchored down to prevent flotation during concrete placement below the springline. (5) upon completion of the river diversion time period, completely fill all culverts installed within the rcc structure with concrete with compressive strength of no less than 3,000 pounds per square inch. c. the existing outlet works pipes may not be used for river diversion. river diversion must occur within the existing spillway channel. d. cofferdams must be designed by a licensed professional engineer in the state of washington. cofferdams must be designed according to usace manuals and regulations cited in the paragraph references. submit cofferdam design for review. submit at least 30 days prior to iww for review. include all relevant sketches, shop drawings, and calculations packages. designs must be peer reviewed by an independent technical reviewer with supporting documentation of that review provided in the package. cofferdams designed and constructed as part of temporary works must have any features not consisting of earth materials removed from the spillway and sediment plain. 3.2 seepage consider the potential for seepage through cofferdams and through the rock foundation beneath cofferdams. design the river diversion system to prevent potential seepage from disrupting construction activities, by minimizing or collecting such potential seepage. 3.3 minimum discharge for river continuity during transitions in river diversions, maintain a minimum discharge of 50 cubic feet per second of the north fork toutle river from the upstream reservoir to the downstream channel. the location of the discharge along the existing spillway crest may vary during construction. measure the discharge in the north fork toutle river at the usgs gage 14240525 located at the fish collection facility downstream of the sediment retention structure. pumping water for river diversion is not allowed in order to protect any fish that may be migrating downstream while the river diversion system is in place. during this minimum discharge, the number of culvert pipes may need to be limited to assure minimum depth criteria (next paragraph) is met. 3.4 minimum flow depth except for transitions described above, maintain a discharge of 340 cfs and a minimum flow depth of one foot to provide passage for any fish that may be migrating downstream while the contractor's river diversion system is in place. a siphon is an acceptable method to pass fish and water. contractor may cut slots through the rcc baffles of the first raise for pipe access. the combination of number and size of pipes must not cause the flow depths to run below minimum depth in the pipes at the median discharge 340 cfs during construction season. 3.5 diversion connectivity to existing low flow channel the river flows down the existing seven foot rcc crest raise wedge to the existing excavated low channel. no flow must be diverted southwest of the section 30 00 01.00 25 page 4 msh sediment retention structure crest raise dashed line (i.e. no diversion area) shown on the contract drawings (c-007). any means of piping, channeling, or berm is acceptable as long as there is no stranding of the fish. clearance of woody vegetation along the conveyance route is required. 3.6 fish rescue provide fisheries biologists or biological technicians during construction of the coffer dam and river division to rescue and relocate any stranded fish. any stranded fish will be rescued immediately and returned directly back into the river. 3.7 demobilization prior to demobilization from the site, all man-made components of the river diversion system must be removed and must remain the property of the contractor. earth materials used in cofferdams may remain in place, however, cofferdam material above the elevation of the crest of the low flow channel must be removed. -- end of
