clearance 12.1 during shift changes, the safe clearance integrity shall be maintained as follows: 12.1.1the off-going pai shall inspect the worksite and communicate with workers to assess the current status of the personnel, equipment, and work covered by the safe clearance. 12.1.2 the off-going pai shall brief the on-coming pai on the current personnel, equipment, and work status. 12.1.3 the on-coming pai shall place their personal lock on the lockbox. 12.1.4 the on-coming pai shall then review the safe clearance and inspect the worksite to ensure the safe clearance is adequate. 12.1.5 when the on-coming pai is satisfied with the integrity of the safe clearance, they will then accept the responsibility for the safe clearance by documenting it in the safe clearance activity log. 12.1.6 the off-going pai shall release responsibility to the on-coming pai by documenting it in the safe clearance activity log. 12.1.7 the off-going pai shall then remove their personal lock from the lockbox. 12.1.8 if there is a question of the integrity or status of the safe clearance, personnel, or work being performed, the off-going pai shall retain responsibility and work will stop until the situation is resolved. a10-29 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure 385-1 safety portland district supplement to usace hazardous energy control program portland district current approved version 18 jan 2020). printed copies are for information only. the controlled version resides on the cenwpod sharepoint portal, libraries at: https://intranet.usace.army.mil/nwd/nwp/od/pages/home.aspx 13.0 transfer of a clearance 13.1 transfers of a clearance are permitted from pai/ai to pai/ai. 13.2 documentation of the transfer is completed by the ii and shall be performed in the following manner. 13.2.1 if the pai/ai holding a safe clearance plans to leave the facility for an extended period of time or needs to transfer the responsibility of a safe clearance to another pai/ai, this intention must be stated to the ii. 13.2.2 the oncoming pai/ai must understand the limits of the safe clearance and any special hazards that exist in connection with the work to be performed under the safe clearance. 13.2.3 the oncoming pai/ai shall then place their personal lock on the lockbox. 13.2.4 the oncoming pai/ai shall review the safe clearance and shall assure that energy isolation devices are properly positioned, locked and tagged. 13.2.5 the oncoming pai/ai will initial each isolation point tag upon verification of that device s position and condition. 13.2.6 after the oncoming pai/ai has documented the transfer in the safe clearance activity log and signed the transfer block of the safe clearance order to accept the safe clearance, the ii will issue the safe clearance to the oncoming pai/ai. 13.2.7 the outgoing pai/ai shall sign the safe clearance order to transfer the safe clearance to the oncoming pai/ai and shall remove their personal lock from the lockbox. 13.2.8 the ii shall record the following information in the station logbook: safe clearance number; date and military time of transfer; and names of individuals transferring the safe clearance. upon transfer of a safe clearance, the word transferred shall be stamped across the corresponding log. 14.0 personal lockout (lockout/tag out without a clearance) 14.1 the responsible official shall designate certain equipment (in writing) which may be removed from service using a personal lockout. personal locks and tags shall be used when removing equipment from service under these conditions. personal lockouts fall under the same requirements as do safe clearances and can only be used by authorized individuals. a10-30 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure 385-1 safety portland district supplement to usace hazardous energy control program portland district current approved version 18 jan 2020). printed copies are for information only. the controlled version resides on the cenwpod sharepoint portal, libraries at: https://intranet.usace.army.mil/nwd/nwp/od/pages/home.aspx 14.2 personal locks and tags shall be used when removing the designated equipment from service. 14.3 personal lockout must be approved and documented in the station log by the ii, including the start time, end time and date. the use of this process is permitted only when the following criteria are met. 14.3.1 an aha shall be prepared and approved that identifies all sources of hazardous energy. 14.3.2 an approved, step-by-step procedure, specific to the piece of equipment being removed from service for multi-point isolation. 14.3.3 the employee is authorized to work only under their own personal locks and tags. 14.3.4 equipment is easily isolated such that the employee can exercise close control over the isolation points. 14.3.5 equipment would not adversely affect the mission. 14.3.6 equipment is rated at 480-volts or lower. 14.3.7 the operation or work to be accomplished is limited to one shift. 14.3.8 a maximum of four isolation points is allowed. 14.3.9 the equipment has no potential for stored or residual energy or accumulation of stored energy after shut down which could endanger employees. 14.3.10 the servicing or maintenance does not create hazards for other employees. 14.3.11 personal lockout shall be recorded in the station logbook. 14.3.12 verification of removal of hazardous energy is required. 15.0 issuing individual (ii) clearance 15.1 ii clearances are temporary, generic clearances not specifically issued to an authorized individual. as such, the issuing and releasing responsibility rests with the ii on shift. a10-31 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure 385-1 safety personnel due to an abnormal equipment condition. 15.3 no maintenance or service shall be performed under the protection of an ii clearance. 15.4 ii clearances are not to be transferred and are only employees are not authorized to work under hold orders. 16.7.2 this procedure is for transmission lines only. 16.7.3 the line remains energized when a hold order is in place. 16.7.4 hold order - assurance given to a worker by a system dispatcher or substation operator that if a transmission line is de-energized, (for any reason) it will not be ordered energized until that worker reports the crew in the clear. 16.7.5 terminal hold - is a formal assurance of non-reclosure at the local terminal or terminals of an inter-connecting circuit provided by the local system dispatcher (or powerhouse operator) to a requesting dispatcher. the terminal hold assures the requesting dispatcher that the terminal or source on hold has sufficient relays in service to provide protection in the event of a fault; and, once tripped out of service, will not be energized, automatically or manually until the dispatcher receiving the terminal hold has advised that all personnel and materials are in the clear and it is safe to energize. 16.7.5.1 a hold order is given on the entire line. a terminal hold is only given to a dispatcher or ph operator from one end and is used in conjunction with other tagging to issue a hold on the entire line to a worker. 16.7.6 a clearance is used in place of a hold order for corps personnel. 16.7.7 hold order procedure: 16.7.7.1 scheduled through operations manager. 16.7.7.2 the ii can schedule terminal hold orders if the operations manager is not available. a10-36 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure 385-1 safety portland district supplement to usace hazardous energy control program portland district current approved version 18 jan 2020). printed copies are for information only. the controlled version resides on the points including gdacs screens. this includes any station service feed on the line. see attachment 5.8 for example of a hold order tag. 16.7.7.4 bpa s dispatcher will coordinate with the ii. 16.7.7.5 ii logs the terminal hold order in the station log. 16.7.7.6 the logbook entry shall be in blue and contain the following: 16.7.7.6.1 the line the hold order is on. 16.7.7.6.2 the requester ex. dittmer generation dispatcher . 16.7.7.6.3 direct phone number of the requester. 16.7.7.6.4 reason. 16.7.7.6.5 stipulation, do not re-energize until after directed by the dispatcher. 16.7.7.7 bpa expects that the line relaying is cut in and operational, no relay maintenance is allowed during this time. 16.7.7.8 automatic re-closers are cut out. 16.7.7.9 the line is not re-energized after a trip. 16.7.9.9.1 only re-energized after directed by bpas dispatcher. 16.7.9.9.2 not necessary to clear the tag after dispatcher requests re-energization. 16.7.7.10 logging requirements for _______. 16.7.7.11 when releasing a hold order: a10-37 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure 385-1 safety portland district supplement to usace hazardous energy control program 18.0 caution orders 18.1 caution orders shall be reviewed by the ro or their designee at least every six months to ensure the caution order is still needed. if used for more than one year, the caution order shall be removed and operating procedures shall be developed to reflect current operational conditions. 18.2 caution orders shall not be used to protect personnel. 18.3 caution orders must be approved and documented by the ii. 18.4 caution orders are issued with direct attention to abnormal or unusual conditions, or to special operating instructions to be followed. 18.5 each caution order shall be assigned an identification number. 18.6 caution orders will be logged in the station logbook. 18.7 eng form 1928, caution order sheet, will be prepared for each caution order issued. this will supplement the station logbook entry at those projects maintaining station logbooks and provide the necessary project records at other projects. records shall be maintained for a minimum of two years. 18.8 eng form 1924, caution order tag, will be properly completed and attached to appropriate control devices and equipment. 19.0 additional items concerning contractors or non-project personnel 19.1 saf 385-1 shall be used for lockout/tag out of all equipment connected to government-owned equipment. an approved contractor hecp can be used in addition to, but never in lieu of, the corps of engineers hecp. 19.2 when usace employees are on a site that is controlled by a contractor and are affected by the contractor-managed hecp, they shall comply with the contractors hecp. the contractors hecp shall be developed iaw 29 cfr 1910.147, ansi z244.1, and ansi a10.44. 19.3 when non-project personnel perform construction or maintenance at government-operated facilities and are exposed to hazardous energy, the non-project personnel shall also be trained in and protected by saf 385-1. a10-39 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure 385-1 safety portland district entity shall implement their hec procedure in coordination with the local issuing individual. the non-usace entity will provide their hec program and procedures to the government designated authority isolated working area, including any unusual conditions. this review will occur at the work site after the clearance is in place and will include a review of the limits of the deenergized and isolated working area, aha, isolation points, work to be completed, and unusual conditions. upon request, the pai holding the safe clearance will walk the isolation as part of the review, review any associated drawings, hand over hand the system, and/or provide the station o&m manual. 19.7.1 each ap is responsible for reviewing the clearance with the pai or superintendent/work leader prior to signing on to the safe clearance. this review will occur at the work site and will include a review of the limits of the de-energized and isolated working area, aha, isolation points, work to be completed, and any unusual conditions. upon the request of any ap signing onto the clearance, the pai holding the safe clearance will walk the isolation as part of the review, review associated drawings, hand over hand the system, and/or provide the station o&m manual. 19.7.2 a pai cannot authorize a superintendent/work leader to sign on to a clearance via telephone or radio. 19.7.3 each affected person working under the group clearance shall sign the safe clearance sign in sheet verifying he or she fully understands the details of their job, the energy isolation devices actuated, the locks and tags installed, and will then place their personal lock on the group lockbox. a10-41 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure 385-1 safety portland district supplement to usace hazardous the adequacy of the protection provided. the first ap shall concur with the method of inspection and be qualified to perform the testing. 19.8.1 the method of testing shall be described on the specific aha for the associated clearance. only the first ap to sign onto the clearance is required to test for the absence of hazardous energy with the pai. the ap and pai who perform the verification/testing shall sign and record this on the safe clearance order. 19.8.2 the pai and/or ap, by signing either the safe clearance order form or safe clearance activity log confirming the absence of hazardous energy, are acknowledging that verification/testing has been performed as described in the aha or activity log and no hazardous energy was detected as of the date and time of their signature 19.8.3 the method of testing for isolation points added after the clearance is accepted, or re-hung after a temporary lift, will be described on the safe clearance activity log. 19.8.4 no other aps shall sign onto the safe clearance sign-in sheet prior to confirming the completion of the verification/testing documentation. 19.8.5 other aps are required to confirm the verification/testing has been completed by observation of the ap s signature on the safe clearance order. if isolation points have been temp lifted and restored, confirmation of the testing signature is recorded on the safe clearance activity sheet. 19.8.6 aps other than the first aps to sign onto the clearance may test the isolation provided it poses no risk to aps already working at the job site protected by the clearance. for example, testing for voltage with a voltmeter doesn t add additional risk to ap s already working on the circuit. attempting to open a spill gate while other aps are working below it does increase the risk of danger to aps working below the spill gate. 19.8.7 work that requires electrical energy to be isolated shall be made electrically safe via a safe clearance and tested as follows: 19.8.7.1 an adequately rated test instrument will be used to test each phase conductor or circuit part to verify it is de-energized. 19.8.7.2 test each phase conductor or circuit part both phase-to-phase and phase-toground. 19.8.7.3 before and after each test, determine that the test instrument is operating a10-42 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure non-standard maintenance. 20.1 non-standard equipment is that which is not directly associated with the generation of hydropower or the flow of water from portland district projects. such equipment includes but is not limited to elevators, escalators, hoists, and other such equipment which require being energized to perform certain required maintenance functions. 2 0 . 2 when manufacturer s standard may be used in lieu of the district hecp unless otherwise directed by the ro or his designated representative. 21.0 abnormal release and removal 21.1 abnormal removal of personal locks. when the individual who applied a personal lock is not available to remove it due to extraordinary circumstances, the individual s immediate supervisor shall assume full responsibility for the removal of the personal lock after performing the following actions. 21.1.1verify that the individual who applied the personal lock is not at the facility. 21.1.2 make all reasonable efforts to contact the individual to inform them that their personal lock will be removed. 21.1.3 ensure that the individual will be informed of the removal before they resume work at that facility by signing the abnormal removal of personal lock form. 21.1.4 obtain written authorization from the ro or their designee to remove the individual s personal lock. a10-43 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure the abnormal release of safe clearance form. 21.2.4 obtain written authorization from the ro or their designee to release the safe clearance and remove the pai/ai s personal lock. 21.2.5 inspected the work area to assure non-essential items/tools have been removed from the system and the system components are operationally intact. 21.2.6 verify tpgs have been released. 21.2.7 ensure all personnel have signed off the safe clearance sign-in sheet and have removed their personal locks from the lockbox. 21.2.8 documentation provided in the abnormal release of safe clearance form must be filled in and attached to the safe clearance as a permanent record of the action. 22.0 records and measurements 22.1 all training records, clearance forms, ahas, and work permits shall be kept on file for a requirements of the hec program are being followed, to identify and correct any weaknesses (or potential weaknesses) in the program or procedures, in employee training, or in how the requirements are enforced. see attachment 7. 23.2 the responsible official shall ensure the periodic inspections are performed. 23.3 periodic inspections shall be performed at least annually by individual(s) knowledgeable in hec program and procedures, to include a qualified person. personnel internal to the facility may conduct the inspection one year and personnel external to the facility shall conduct the inspection the next year (peer review). the person using the hec procedure cannot inspect the procedure. 23.4 periodic inspections of hec procedures shall cover at least one lockout/tag out without a clearance and a safe clearance in progress, the procedure details and include a review between the inspectors and individuals involved in the safe clearance being inspected. 23.5 inspections shall be documented (date, persons involved, results) and identified deficiencies noted. corrective actions taken to improve the program or employee knowledge of the program must include how any revision of specific procedures or a general change is communicated to the workers. a10-45 cenwp-od-saf-385-1 cenwp-od standing safety procedure 385-1 safety portland district supplement to usace portland district hazardous energy control program self inspection checklist references refer to: er 385-1-31 the control of hazardous energy 1 nov 2009 yes no n/a item please use your initials to mark these columns 1. has the responsible official (ro) established a hec program at their respective project? 2. has the ro designated in writing the occupants and responsibilities of the following positions: er 385-1-31, 2-2c a. issuing individual (ii)? b. designated representative to the issuing individual (drll)? c. principal authorized individual (pai)? d. authorized individual(s) (al)? 3. has the ro designated in writing any special conditions at the project? 4. has the ro established a safe clearance committee to evaluate the hecp: er 385-1-31, 11-1 5. is the hecp reviewed (evaluated) and updated annually? 6. does the project perform annual inspections of their hecp procedures? er 385-1-31,11-3 a. do these inspections include a safe clearance in progress? er 385-1-31, 11-4 b. do these inspections include one lockout/tag out without a safe clearance? er 385-1-31, 11-4 c. do these inspections include a review of the procedural details? er 385-1-31, 11-4 d. do these inspections include a review between the inspector and the individuals involved in the safe clearance do these inspections document (date, persons involved, results) and identify deficiencies f. are inspection results forwarded to the ro? g. is the inspection documentation kept for a minimum of five (5) years? 7. is project documentation available to all persons involved with issuing and holding safe clearances? er 385-1-31, 2-2.i 8. does the project hec training program require initial, annual, and as-required retraining? er 385-1-31, 2 a. does annual retraining include a written assessment? er 385-1-31, b. is training documentation maintained on file for at least two (2) years? er 385-1-31, 5-2 c. is retraining conducted when there is an unauthorized deviation from hec procedures, demonstrated lack of employee knowledge, change in assignment, change in hazards, or change in the hecp? er 385-1-31, 5-4.b and c 9. are training records, clearance logs, forms, work permits, inspections reports kept for a minimum of 2 years? er 385-1-31 10. does the issuing individual direct the switching/clearing and related operations needed to place and remove clearances 11. does the issuing individual accept and release safe clearances for the following conditions: a. line terminal clearances on tie lines? b. supply lines to and from outside utilities/agencies? 12. does the designated representative to the issuing individual assure proper positioning of energy isolation devices? 13. does the pai place appropriate locks on energy isolation devices after verifying they've been properly switched & tagged 14. does the pai report the start and completion of energy isolation procedures? er 385-1-31 15. does the pai use an activity hazard analysis (aha) to identify and analyze all hazardous energy sources for the work to be performed? er 385-1-31, 1-5.b and 7-2.b.(1).(a) a. is a current aha utilized for each activity requiring a safe clearance? er 385-1-31, 1.5b 17. is each lock uniquely marked for identification? b. are locks identifiable as hecp locks and standardized within the facility? er 385-1-31, 6-1.b c. are personal locks used solely for personal protection and no other purpose? 18. do tags identify to whom the safe clearance is issued? er 385-1-31, 6-2.d a. does the pai or al initial each isolation point tag upon verification of that device's position and condition? 19. does the pai or ii sign the safe clearance order? 20. are public access area protected with both locks and tags? er 385-1-31, 7-1.d 21. is computer software or any other type of programming prohibited for use as an isolation point? 22. are group lockboxes afforded positive control when in use? er 385-1-31, 23. when the relevant individual is not available or an abnormal condition is declared, does the ro or designee provide written authorization to remove that individual's personal lock? er 385-1-31, 7-5.b-h 24. has the ro identified personnel who can utilize personal lockout? a10-78 remarks: inspectors: signature date printed name title and organization signature date printed name title and organization portland district hazardous energy control
